item.title: Love is Hard, HIV Prevention is Easy website
item.dc:creator: baoanhbui
item.description: UI/UX design for a public health campaign website to raise awareness about HIV prevention, reduce new HIV infections, and eliminate HIV stigma in Vietnam–Love is Hard, HIV Prevention is Easy. The website acts as an online repository for the public audience to learn about the issues and the campaign itself. Visit yeumoikho.com to see website.
item.content:encoded:
UI/UX design for a public health campaign website to raise awareness about HIV prevention, reduce new HIV infections, and eliminate HIV stigma in Vietnam–Love is Hard, HIV Prevention is Easy. The website acts as an online repository for the public audience to learn about the issues and the campaign itself.

Visit yeumoikho.com to see website.

  • Bảo Anh as UI/UX designer
  • Khê Nguyễn as UI/UX designer
  • Trang Đinh as UI/UX designer
  • Tuân Lê as Creative director
  • Digitop for web development
  • Work done as part of ‘LOVE IS HARD. HIV PREVENTION IS EASY.’ communication campagin by The Lab Saigon

item.title: Vietnamme Magazine
item.dc:creator: baoanhbui
item.description: Vietnamme, an art organization in Vietnam, had been proposing the idea of a web magazine platform dedicated to exploring how the youth redefine and push the boundaries of art, irrespective of its form. I’m initially tasked with producing digital illustrations for two articles within the magazine.
item.content:encoded:
Vietnamme, an art organization in Vietnam, had been proposing the idea of a web magazine platform dedicated to exploring how the youth redefine and push the boundaries of art, irrespective of its form. I’m initially tasked with producing digital illustrations for two articles within the magazine.

  • Bảo Anh as website co-developer, website designer and illustrator
  • Diệu Ly as website co-developer and graphic designer
  • Minh Anh, and My Hà as graphic designer
  • Minh Phương, Anh Huy, and Chi Doan as illustrator
  • Vietnamme Magazine team for other content, and copy

item.title: trămđốt
item.dc:creator: baoanhbui
item.description: After the closure of Ươm, a renowned hangout in Saigon’s creative scene, its founder, ltlt.company, has transitioned its legacy into the digital world with their latest cultural platform, trămđốt. trămđốt design tries capture the nostalgic aesthetics of massively multiplayer online games (MMOs) from the 2010s. These games, including titles like Club Penguin or the Vietnamese […]
item.content:encoded:
After the closure of Ươm, a renowned hangout in Saigon’s creative scene, its founder, ltlt.company, has transitioned its legacy into the digital world with their latest cultural platform, trămđốt.

trămđốt design tries capture the nostalgic aesthetics of massively multiplayer online games (MMOs) from the 2010s. These games, including titles like Club Penguin or the Vietnamese equivalents like Online Gunny and Bang Bang, were immensely popular among our generation.

For social media, I created this fun create-your-own-ASCII web for the audience to have their personalized ASCII person, using our idiosyncratic font. You can try here https://nguoi.tramdot.app/

It’s nice that it created a lot of attention. Thanks to all the friends to try on our small little fun mascot.

  • Bao Anh as graphic designer
  • Hải Phan & Tùng Sơn Lê as web developers
  • Duy Anh & Lê Minh as project director
  • chị Thy as project manager
  • This work is done for ltlt.company/trămđốt

item.title: vanghoa.github.io
item.dc:creator: baoanhbui
item.description: This marked my first time developing a website entirely from scratch, without the use of plugins or web-building tools. I hand-coded the site using only plain HTML, CSS, and vanilla JavaScript, then slapped it up on Github Pages as a static website. All that stuff I’d been accumulating from my past projects, from Semplice, from […]
item.content:encoded:
• Visit the vanghoa.github.io to see the website.
  • Take a look at the github repository.

This marked my first time developing a website entirely from scratch, without the use of plugins or web-building tools. I hand-coded the site using only plain HTML, CSS, and vanilla JavaScript, then slapped it up on Github Pages as a static website.

All that stuff I’d been accumulating from my past projects, from Semplice, from Webflow, from Javascriptinfo and more, it all clicked into place. This experience was like connecting the dots and seeing my knowledge come to life. Plus, it wasn’t just about making sense of what I already knew – I got to build more on top of it during the process. Amazing!

  • Bảo Anh as UI/UX designer and web developer
  • Big thanks to Stack Overflow for all the solutions to my problems

item.title: The navigation bar that is in the middle of nowhere
item.dc:creator: baoanhbui
item.description: The concept of the “navigation bar in the middle of nowhere” had been on my checklist for a while. It could be seen as an additional meaning layer on top of the navigation bar surrounding the four sides on my previous ‘Personal website 2022’. Initially, the website’s objective is to archive all of my video […]
item.content:encoded:
• Visit the vanghoa.github.io/vlog-template/ to see the website.
  • Take a look at the github repository.

The concept of the “navigation bar in the middle of nowhere” had been on my checklist for a while. It could be seen as an additional meaning layer on top of the navigation bar surrounding the four sides on my previous ‘Personal website 2022’.

Initially, the website’s objective is to archive all of my video footages and images during my internship at Practice Theory. The idea was to use the site as a presentation platform for my vlogs, where I would screen record and narrate them using my voice. It was a convenient way to showcase my experiences and work on a weekly basis.

  • Bảo Anh as web developer
  • The website was done as part of an assignment at LASALLE College of the Arts
  • Some materials of the site are from studio Practice Theory

item.content:encoded:

item.title: Nam Bắc Một Nhà
item.dc:creator: baoanhbui
item.description: Despite the reunification of Vietnam nearly 50 years ago, the division between the people from the North and South Vietnam still remains, a lingering result of the Vietnam War. This project, “Nam Bắc Một Nhà,” envisions a National Reconciliation Day that aims to celebrate all memories of the Vietnam War, particularly those that have been […]
item.content:encoded:
Despite the reunification of Vietnam nearly 50 years ago, the division between the people from the North and South Vietnam still remains, a lingering result of the Vietnam War. This project, “Nam Bắc Một Nhà,” envisions a National Reconciliation Day that aims to celebrate all memories of the Vietnam War, particularly those that have been suppressed, avoided, or ignored by both the general public and the Vietnamese governments.

  • Visit nam-bac-mot-nha.vercel.app to see!
  • Take a look at the github repository of the site.

Besides the usual touchpoints, I found the adaptation of street signs to be particularly interesting. One of the subtle nuances of the Reunification event is the change in street names that occurred during the transition period between the two governments.

I wanted to use the yellow scarf as a touchpoint. It’s a reference to the iconic red scarf or ‘khăn quàng đỏ,’ which was mandatory for students as part of their school uniform.

When designing print materials, I intentionally chose to work with materials and formats that are ubiquitously recognized in the Vietnamese context.

The “Bleed Notes” have a hollow center, preserving only the bleed area (hence their name), which is typically discarded during the printing process. They were crafted from the remnants of the main Brand Styleguide book.

You can view the scanned version of the Bleed Notes online here nam-bac-mot-nha.vercel.app/bleednotes

Continuing the theme of incorporating local print inspirations from the Brand Styleguide book, this time I used student notebooks that I brought way from Vietnam as materials for the CPJ.

A notebook that contained ready-made envelopes. Each piece of paper inside is instructed to be folded into an envelope.

The posters were designed to be adaptable and incorporate various illustration styles, drawing inspiration from historical propaganda posters during the war, as showcased in the examples below.

This website adhered to the visual identity, incorporating slanted strokes as the primary design ingredients.

For the digital Creative Process Journal, I wanted to spice it up by wrapping the text content below the 2 slanted strokes. It gives a fun visual twist on scroll, and those slanted lines work as scrollbars.

I’m so happy that it received the Creative Conscience Award 2023 and got featured on Slanted Magazine #42 – Books!

Thanks to everyone who helped me throughout this project, one way or another:

Special thanks to Giun Trym, Tường Vi Ng, my lecturers Joselyn, Felix, and Joanne, chị Ven, chị Tường Nguyên, anh Triết, chị Nhung, chị Phương, my dad, my mom, my grandparents, my uncle, Duy Psycoreboy, anh Tân, chị Trang, Pauline, Eka, Joseph, Tiara, Vũ Phạm, Hải Vân, Ziêm, Sinprint print shop near Burger King, and a shoutout to the display font I used–’Bourrasque’ from Bureau Brut.

item.title: Form & Agency
item.dc:creator: baoanhbui
item.description: Form & Agency exhibition by Brandon Tay introduces a body of work that explores the materiality of the digital, through an engagement with 3D-printed sculptures, live-simulations, and virtual ecosystems. The exhibition’s visual identity, designed by Darius Ou, specifically places a spotlight on the variable typeface As Above, So Below. This typeface, characterized by its elongated […]
item.content:encoded:
Form & Agency exhibition by Brandon Tay introduces a body of work that explores the materiality of the digital, through an engagement with 3D-printed sculptures, live-simulations, and virtual ecosystems.

The exhibition’s visual identity, designed by Darius Ou, specifically places a spotlight on the variable typeface As Above, So Below. This typeface, characterized by its elongated ascenders and descenders, deliberately echoes the verticality of the stacks. It boasts the unique capability of forming ‘vertical ligatures’ not between adjacent letters but across lines of text.

However, there isn’t an existing OpenType feature for this particular type of ‘weird’ ligature. Moreover, creating the vertical ligature is a more intricate technical process than the usual ligature because it relies on the positioning of letters vertically adjacent, which can shift significantly when we adjust the width of the text box.

That’s when Darius approached me for a collaboration, with the goal of bringing this feature to life through coding.

  • Visit the exhibition site here formandagency.net or formandagency.vercel.app
  • Take a look at the github repository.
  • Visit the “type generation tool” site here vanghoa.github.io/AsAboveSoBelow/oldsite/
  • Take a look at the github repository.
  • Visit the “AI text” site here vanghoa.github.io/AsAboveSoBelow/.
  • Take a look at the github repository.
  • Bảo Anh as web designer and creative coder
  • Darius Ou as design director and graphic designer
  • This project was done for Brandon Tay’s exhibition–Form and Agency, curated by Rafi Abdullah
